Description: Indicates the total number of Java installations detected on the host.
Interpretation: A higher value may indicate multiple Java runtimes or SDKs installed, which can complicate maintenance, patching, and security hardening.

Description: Indicates the number of Java installations that are not located under standard 'Program Files' directories.
Interpretation: Java runtimes installed outside standard locations may bypass standard administrative controls and hardening guidelines, increasing the risk of unmanaged or vulnerable Java installations.

Description: Indicates the number of Java processes that are currently running on the host.
Interpretation: A higher value may indicate multiple Java-based applications or services running simultaneously, which can increase resource utilization and broaden the security attack surface.

Measurement: Java processes running without Xmx settings
Description: Indicates the number of Java processes started without an explicit -Xmx maximum heap setting.
Interpretation: Processes without an explicit -Xmx may rely on JVM defaults, which can lead to unpredictable memory usage, potential out-of-memory errors, or over-consumption of system memory under load.

Measurement: Java processes running with multiple Xmx settings
Description: Indicates the number of Java processes that have multiple -Xmx options specified in their startup arguments.
Interpretation: Multiple -Xmx options can lead to configuration ambiguity and maintenance issues; only one value is used by the JVM, and misconfiguration may cause incorrect assumptions about effective heap limits.

Measurement: Java processes with passwords in arguments
Description: Indicates the number of Java processes whose command-line arguments contain passwords or other sensitive credentials.
Interpretation: Passing passwords on the command line is insecure because process arguments can often be viewed by other users and logging tools, leading to potential credential exposure.

Measurement: Java processes with MaxRAMPercentage in arguments
Description: Indicates the number of Java processes started with the -XX:MaxRAMPercentage option in their arguments.
Interpretation: Using MaxRAMPercentage allows heap sizing based on container or system memory; improper values may lead to either under-utilization of memory or excessive heap allocation that starves other processes.

Description: Indicates the number of Java processes where initial heap (-Xms) and maximum heap (-Xmx) settings are configured inconsistently with recommended sizing policies.
Interpretation: Inconsistent Xms/Xmx settings can cause excessive heap resizing, unpredictable GC behavior, or inefficient memory usage, impacting performance and stability of Java applications.
